Description: These sensing knowledge feeders don’t require a significant amount of cognition to deliver effective results. Ants emit pheromones that enhance their collective behavior by making each individual ant a sensor of the environment around them. This optimizes routes used for the scouting of food with remarkable accuracy. Interestingly, ants don’t just optimize the search direction. They also optimize the amount of “ant resources” deployed in the search, to ensure their collective energy is used correctly at the right time. Some do so by simply modulating the speed of exit from the anthill, achieved by sensing the speed of incoming ants. Returning ants bump into those who are ready to exit. The faster the rate of return (signaling more food available, because it took less time to find it) the more ants are sent out. A bee’s “dance” serves a similar purpose.
The takeover of Afghanistan in 2021 by the Taliban is a somber reminder of how effective the pervasive use of comparatively simple collaboration technology (in this case, WhatsApp groups) can be.

Use case: Verify provenance and authenticity of web information
Description: The Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity is a consortium backed by ARM, Twitter and Microsoft that issued a protocol with guidelines for disclosure of information. This protocol uses a technique called hard binding, which uses crypotgraphy to encode and bind information together to facilitate auditability. The News Provenance Project uses cryptography to provide confidence on news reporting.

Can ecosystems decide? Ecosystems benefit from the natural experiments that happen in loosely connected parts of the network and can provide significant creativity as well as resiliency. They’re however harder to align and control. Nature effectively chooses, over time, based on alternatives created by mutations of genes and the environment; it expresses those genes in the short term through epigenetics (for instance metabolic changes in response to a famine, transmitted to the next generation); and mutations of RNA seem to show longer-term "memory" of the reaction to biological event (such as in the case of mounting a defense to a bacteria)

Crowdsourcing tool that enables people who have been the targets of harassment to coordinate “squads” of friends to filter messages and support them during attacks.  https://news.mit.edu/2018/using-friends-to-fight-online-harassment-0405

Use case: Form a combined perception of reality
Description: According to Jeff Hawkins' "Thousand Brains" theory, the brain does not contain one model of the world; it contains thousands of complementary models for everything we know. The models vote together to produce our singular perception.

Use case: Launch crowdsourced cyberattacks during military conflict
Description: During the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, a reported 300,000 global and self-organized non-combatants supported cyberattacks on Russian IT infrastructure.

The international consortium of investigative journalism (ICIJ) provides a platform to anyone who can contribute to investigations. The platform is called Datashare and apart from facilitating various types of human workflows, utilizes advanced knowledge graph databases that leverage technologies like Neo4J (to structure data) and Linkurious (for visualization).

Use case: Detect online scams and improve information security
Description: Enterprise email users can contribute to the detection of phishing scams that might have eluded the cybersecurity protection layer. Companies increasingly make it easy for users to report suspicious email, that are then examined by the information security team, and potentially filtered before they land into other users' inboxes.
